docs.lead_paragraph: Many psychiatrists, in large part because of how much insurance will pay, no longer provide talk therapy.

headline.main: Talk Doesn’t Pay, So Psychiatry Turns Instead to Drug Therapy
headline.print_headline: DOCTORS INC.; Talk Doesn’t Pay, So Psychiatry Turns Instead to Drug Therapy

docs.snippet: Many psychiatrists, in large part because of how much insurance will pay, no longer provide talk therapy.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, I wrote about how a health worker named Reynaldo Rodriguez worked with a patient, Joe McManus, to help him stick to his treatment plan to control his AIDS and Hepatitis C. Most of us don't have the multiple serious illnesses and problems that  McManus does, but a lot of us still share his basic challenge: how do we get ourselves to live more healthfully?    We might need to eat better, quit smoking or drinking or exercise more.  Instead of thinking of it as treatment adherence, we might call it keeping our New Year's resolutions.
docs.abstract: Most of us have people close to us who can help us stick to our health regimens even if they have no medical training at all.
docs.snippet: Most of us have people close to us who can help us stick to our health regimens even if they have no medical training at all.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes even well-informed patients have blinders on about the potential of a treatment or clinical trial, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in the latest Doctor and Patient column.
docs.abstract: Sometimes even well-informed patients have blinders on about the potential of a treatment or clinical trial.
docs.snippet: Sometimes even well-informed patients have blinders on about the potential of a treatment or clinical trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients think experimental cancer drugs will work for them, even though fewer than 5 percent ever benefit from early-phase studies.

headline.print_headline: The Unrealistic Optimism of Cancer Patients

docs.snippet: Patients think experimental cancer drugs will work for them, even though fewer than 5 percent ever benefit from early-phase studies.
